segment.source: When you want to access a large collection of files and you want to access property values other than the typical Name, FileType, and Path properties, access them by creating QueryOptions and calling SetPropertyPrefetch.
segment.target: When you want to access a large collection of files and you want to access property values other than the typical Name, FileType, and Path properties, access them by creating QueryOptions and calling SetPropertyPrefetch.

segment.source: The SetPropertyPrefetch method can dramatically improve the performance of apps that display a collection of items obtained from the file system, such as a collection of images.
segment.target: The SetPropertyPrefetch method can dramatically improve the performance of apps that display a collection of items obtained from the file system, such as a collection of images.

segment.source: The next set of examples shows a few ways to access multiple files.

segment.target: The first example uses Windows.Storage.StorageFolder.GetFilesAsync to retrieve the name info for a set of files.

segment.target: This approach provides good performance, because the example accesses only the name property.

segment.source: The second example uses Windows.Storage.StorageFolder.GetFilesAsync and then retrieves the image properties for each file.

segment.source: This approach provides much better performance than the previous example.

segment.source: Buffering between UWP and .NET streams
segment.target: Buffering between UWP and .NET streams

segment.source: There are many scenarios when you might want to convert a UWP stream (such as a Windows.Storage.Streams.IInputStream or IOutputStream) to a .NET stream (System.IO.Stream).
segment.target: There are many scenarios when you might want to convert a UWP stream (such as a Windows.Storage.Streams.IInputStream or IOutputStream) to a .NET stream (System.IO.Stream).

segment.source: For example, this is useful when you are writing a UWP app and want to use existing .NET code that works on streams with the UWP file system.
segment.target: For example, this is useful when you are writing a UWP app and want to use existing .NET code that works on streams with the UWP file system.

segment.source: In order to enable this, .NET APIs for Windows Store apps provides extension methods that allow you to convert between .NET and UWP stream types.
segment.target: In order to enable this, .NET APIs for Windows Store apps provides extension methods that allow you to convert between .NET and UWP stream types.

segment.source: For more info, see WindowsRuntimeStreamExtensions.
segment.target: For more info, see WindowsRuntimeStreamExtensions.

segment.source: When you convert a UWP stream to a .NET stream, you effectively create an adapter for the underlying UWP stream.
segment.target: When you convert a UWP stream to a .NET stream, you effectively create an adapter for the underlying UWP stream.

segment.source: Under some circumstances, there is a runtime cost associated with invoking methods on UWP streams.
segment.target: Under some circumstances, there is a runtime cost associated with invoking methods on UWP streams.

segment.source: This may affect the speed of your app, especially in scenarios where you perform many small, frequent read or write operations.
segment.target: This may affect the speed of your app, especially in scenarios where you perform many small, frequent read or write operations.

segment.source: In order to speed up apps, the UWP stream adapters contain a data buffer.
segment.target: In order to speed up apps, the UWP stream adapters contain a data buffer.

segment.source: The following code sample demonstrates small consecutive reads using a UWP stream adapter with a default buffer size.
segment.target: The following code sample demonstrates small consecutive reads using a UWP stream adapter with a default buffer size.

segment.source: This default buffering behavior is desirable in most scenarios where you convert a UWP stream to a .NET stream.
segment.target: This default buffering behavior is desirable in most scenarios where you convert a UWP stream to a .NET stream.

segment.source: However, in some scenarios you may want to tweak the buffering behavior in order to increase performance.
segment.target: However, in some scenarios you may want to tweak the buffering behavior in order to increase performance.

segment.source: Working with large data sets
segment.target: Working with large data sets

segment.source: When reading or writing larger sets of data you may be able to increase your read or write throughput by providing a large buffer size to the AsStreamForRead, AsStreamForWrite, and AsStream extension methods.
segment.target: When reading or writing larger sets of data you may be able to increase your read or write throughput by providing a large buffer size to the AsStreamForRead, AsStreamForWrite, and AsStream extension methods.

segment.source: This gives the stream adapter a larger internal buffer size.
segment.target: This gives the stream adapter a larger internal buffer size.

segment.source: For instance, when passing a stream that comes from a large file to an XML parser, the parser can make many sequential small reads from the stream.
segment.target: For instance, when passing a stream that comes from a large file to an XML parser, the parser can make many sequential small reads from the stream.

segment.source: A large buffer can reduce the number of calls to the underlying UWP stream and boost performance.
segment.target: A large buffer can reduce the number of calls to the underlying UWP stream and boost performance.

segment.source: Note You should be careful when setting a buffer size that is larger than approximately 80 KB, as this may cause fragmentation on the garbage collector heap (see Improve garbage collection performance).
segment.target: Note You should be careful when setting a buffer size that is larger than approximately 80 KB, as this may cause fragmentation on the garbage collector heap (see Improve garbage collection performance).

segment.source: The following code example creates a managed stream adapter with an 81,920 byte buffer.
segment.target: The following code example creates a managed stream adapter with an 81,920 byte buffer.

segment.source: The Stream.CopyTo and CopyToAsync methods also allocate a local buffer for copying between streams.
segment.target: The Stream.CopyTo and CopyToAsync methods also allocate a local buffer for copying between streams.

segment.source: As with the AsStreamForRead extension method, you may be able to get better performance for large stream copies by overriding the default buffer size.
segment.target: As with the AsStreamForRead extension method, you may be able to get better performance for large stream copies by overriding the default buffer size.

segment.source: The following code example demonstrates changing the default buffer size of a CopyToAsync call.
segment.target: The following code example demonstrates changing the default buffer size of a CopyToAsync call.

segment.source: This example uses a buffer size of 1 MB, which is greater than the 80 KB previously recommended.
segment.target: This example uses a buffer size of 1 MB, which is greater than the 80 KB previously recommended.

segment.source: Using such a large buffer can improve throughput of the copy operation for very large data sets (that is, several hundred megabytes).
segment.target: Using such a large buffer can improve throughput of the copy operation for very large data sets (that is, several hundred megabytes).

segment.source: However, this buffer is allocated on the large object heap and could potentially degrade garbage collection performance.
segment.target: However, this buffer is allocated on the large object heap and could potentially degrade garbage collection performance.

segment.source: You should only use large buffer sizes if it will noticeably improve the performance of your app.
segment.target: You should only use large buffer sizes if it will noticeably improve the performance of your app.

segment.source: When you are working with a large number of streams simultaneously, you might want to reduce or eliminate the memory overhead of the buffer.
segment.target: When you are working with a large number of streams simultaneously, you might want to reduce or eliminate the memory overhead of the buffer.

segment.source: You can specify a smaller buffer, or set the bufferSize parameter to 0 to turn off buffering entirely for that stream adapter.
segment.target: You can specify a smaller buffer, or set the bufferSize parameter to 0 to turn off buffering entirely for that stream adapter.

segment.source: You can still achieve good throughput performance without buffering if you perform large reads and writes to the managed stream.
segment.target: You can still achieve good throughput performance without buffering if you perform large reads and writes to the managed stream.

segment.source: Performing latency-sensitive operations
segment.target: Performing latency-sensitive operations

segment.source: You might also want to avoid buffering if you want low-latency reads and writes and do not want to read in large blocks out of the underlying UWP stream.
segment.target: You might also want to avoid buffering if you want low-latency reads and writes and do not want to read in large blocks out of the underlying UWP stream.

segment.source: For example, you might want low-latency reads and writes if you are using the stream for network communications.
segment.target: For example, you might want low-latency reads and writes if you are using the stream for network communications.

segment.source: In a chat app you might use a stream over a network interface to send messages back in forth.
segment.target: In a chat app you might use a stream over a network interface to send messages back in forth.

segment.source: In this case you want to send messages as soon as they are ready and not wait for the buffer to fill up.
segment.target: In this case you want to send messages as soon as they are ready and not wait for the buffer to fill up.

segment.source: If you set the buffer size to 0 when calling the AsStreamForRead, AsStreamForWrite, and AsStream extension methods, then the resulting adapter will not allocate a buffer, and all calls will manipulate the underlying UWP stream directly.
segment.target: If you set the buffer size to 0 when calling the AsStreamForRead, AsStreamForWrite, and AsStream extension methods, then the resulting adapter will not allocate a buffer, and all calls will manipulate the underlying UWP stream directly.
